import sqldump with tables one by one
codex: for SQL in ./testing/*.sql; mysql -h 127.0.0.1 -u root -P 3366 databasename -pc8JQ5J4a < $SQL;

tip: sqldump all tables one by one from a database
codex:
for T in `mysql --skip-column-names -h 127.0.0.1 -u root -P 3366 -e 'show tables from databasename' -pc8JjJ4a`; do echo $T; mysqldump -u root -h 127.0.0.1 -P 3366 databasename $T -pc8JjQ5J4a --set-gtid-purged=OFF --column-statistics=0 > $T.sql; done;
for T in `mysql -h 127.0.0.1 -u root -P 3366 -e 'show tables from databasename' -pc8JjAQ5J4a`; if [[ $T != *Table* ]]; then mysqldump -u root -h 127.0.0.1 -P 3366 databasename $T -pc8JjMQ5J4a --set-gtid-purged=OFF --column-statistics=0 > $T.sql; else continue; fi;

let branches = ["Abu Dhabi", "Al Ain", "Dubai", "Fujairah", "Ras al-Khaimah", "Sharjah", "Ajman"];

for (const branch of branches) {
console.log(branch);
await ...;
}

const { exec } = require("child_process");

desc('Runner Task');
task('run', function (environment, country) {
exec("ls -la", (error, stdout, stderr) => {
if (error) {
console.log(`error: ${error.message}`);
return;
}
if (stderr) {
console.log(`stderr: ${stderr}`);
return;
}
console.log(`stdout: ${stdout}`);
});
});

tip: access Docker commands in Amazon Linux2 ec2-user
codex:
sudo usermod -a -G docker ec2-user
sudo chmod 666 /var/run/docker.sock
docker version

tip: install & start Docker in Amazon Linux2
codex:
sudo yum update -y
sudo yum -y install docker

sudo service docker start
